title: Gret Glyer interviews Jonathan Pageau and I on living overseas
description:
Gret hosted a Hangout on the Air https://youtu.be/TnjF2SxcIBU

Gret's organization https://donorsee.com/ 

Jonathan Pageau's Channel https://www.youtube.com/user/pageaujonathan

For the audio podcast mirror on Podbean http://paulvanderklay.podbean.com/

To listen to this on ITunes https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/paul-vanderklays-podcast/id1394314333 

If you need the RSS feed for your podcast player https://paulvanderklay.podbean.com/feed/ 

To support this channel/podcast on Patreon https://www.patreon.com/paulvanderklay

Join the Sacramento JBP Meetup https://www.meetup.com/Sacramento-Jordan-Peterson-Meetup/

Paul's Church Content at Living Stones Channel https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCh7bdktIALZ9Nq41oVCvW-A

You can donate to Living Stones CRC to support this work here http://www.livingstonescrc.org/donate 
Donations may be tax deductible for taxpayers of the United States

transcript_parts.text: hello everyone and welcome to the show
today I am very honored and pleased to
have Paul van der clay and Jonathan
pooja here with me the two of them I
have introductions right now for each of
them so Jonathan pazzo is creating
YouTube videos exploring symbolism in
religion art as well as in general and
popular culture he explores the patterns
which underlie our experience of the
world how these patterns emerge and come
together and how they are glimpses of
something more
paul van der clay is a minister in the
Christian Reformed Church of North
America he pastors livingstone crc in
sacramento california he enjoys
pastoring a small congregation because
he enjoys the people and he also enjoys
thinking through his faith and
discussing it with others thank you both
for being here is there anything I left
out of that introduction sounds good
except I'm also yeah I'm also an artist
I guess I'm also a icon carver and so
half of my time is spent making icon
carvings in wood and stone and also some
traditional drawings and that's that's
how I share my time with with the
youtubing right I was just interested to
hear how you'd summarize me because I
still really don't know what I'm doing
I'm just having fun really well the
topic of conversation today is how our
times overseas changed our perspective
and I thought that this would be an
interesting conversation because we've
all spent a significant amount of time
overseas so before we get started I'll
quickly say what I did overseas and what
I'm doing now and then you guys can so
that I spent three years living in
Malawi Africa from 2013 to 2016 while I
was over there
two of the three years it was ranked as
the poorest country in the planet and I
went over there originally to be a
teacher and then eventually just started
doing poverty alleviation work and then
now I run an organization that continues
that it's called donor C and I'm very
interested in talking to people who have
had experiences overseas because there
seems to be a level of there's a
commonality between everyone even though
we've all lived in different places so
well where do you want to begin
I I lived I lived in the Dominican
Republic from 1990 to 1997 I was a
missionary with Christian Reformed World
Missions I probably had the the cushiest
experience of the three of us it's it's
a strange it's a strange thing often
living as and called an extern Hetal in
a place like the Dominican Republic
because by virtue of your white skin and
your passport you received a certain
amount of status and deference and I I
went to the Dominican Republic right
after seminary my wife was I was
planning on probably doing inner-city
ministry like my father had that's the
context in which I grew up but my wife
very much wanted to do foreign work so
we wound up going to the Dominican
Republic and it was my first it was my
first job really adult job out of
seminary and it deeply shaped me but but
probably along the lines of my father
had done cross-cultural ministry in
Paterson New Jersey and with the
african-american population that had
migrated up there between the wars and
that was the context in which I grew up
and then the other side of my life was
this strange Dutch Calvinist Enclave
that the Christian Reformed Church is
and so I've always lived in these little
subculture bubbles and I think though
the one thing that I received most from
this was was the experience of not
imagining that not not defaulting to the
perspective that there is a normal way
of being everything is contextualized so
I'd say that that begins you know my
commentary well I I was in Congo for I
was in Africa from 2003 to 2010 so seven
years also part of that about half of
that a bit more was four years in Congo
and then three years in Kenya I worked
with artisans been both places helping
artisans
to to design their product helping them
to market them internationally but also
kind of help them with their marketing
skills locally as well and I worked in
collaboration with 10,000 villages who
buy they buy crafts from all over the
world and they sell that in the United
States and in Canada and now still today
I'm still on the the national board over
10,000 villages in Canada so I think I
think the biggest thing that I learned
in Africa which was which I still kind
of bring with me today in terms of my
own life let's say is I realize just how
much change happens first in people's
minds and how much it happens in
people's attitudes towards life and and
their perception also the perception of
what's possible and also the perception
of their place in the world and so
that's how we ended up organizing my
wife and I work together that's how we
ended up organizing our work in in Congo
and in Kenya working with local people
especially finding local people that
were extremely successful and that had
kind of been able to surmount the
difficulties of living in in poverty and
living in challenging countries that
have failed States you know in Congo is
definitely as basically a failed state
and so finding those people that had had
succeeded and then partnering with them
so that they can try to change the way
people think about their place in the
world and how what impact they could
have in the world because we could
really do it ourselves because like Paul
said we were coming from the outside we
came from you know what for a lot of
Congolese they saw as this perfect world
where everything runs perfectly and
everything's behind what isn't true but
so that that was their perfection that
they're there their vision of it and so
because of that it was difficult to
actually have influence on people
whereas if you if you teamed up with
someone that you could identify there
and you gave them the power to to affect
change then we saw we saw we saw quite a
bit of things happening and so the
project that we started in Kinshasa we
started a local local store and and with
a group of about 20-something artisans
and I'm happy to say that that was in
2004 and we've been gone since since
what like 2006 and it's still going like
the store is still running and totally
locally with local people obviously some
of the artisans have changed or not
working with all the same artisans but
but the the project is still there and
it's still still going so so so I feel
like that has kind of indicated this
idea of working really locally as much
as possible and just kind of working
with people that are there instead of
just coming in and a UN style with your
your company you know here we're gonna
use in our priorities and we've got 10
million dollars and I'm not gonna just
pour it in and then they leave and
there's nothing left except for someone
few people with nice cars well that's a
truly remarkable story will you just
share that that you left there in 2006
and your your efforts from your time
there and the people that you work with
there are continuing on that I say
exceptional because it's it's remarkable
that you were able to accomplish that
and it's also exceptional and that it
doesn't happen very often
and so that's congratulations on that
that's that's really wonderful to hear
what before to kind of like set the
stage for the the thrust of this
conversation what we're talking about is
how our perspectives change by spending
time overseas and so implied in the
topic is that our assumptions did share
our perspectives did change so I'm
assuming that you didn't go overseas and
come back and there was just like you
know nothing different in your mind so
there was something that fundamental
that that change and so I'm wondering
what were some of your your perspectives
that you held before you left to go
overseas I think when I went to the
Dominican Republic as a snot-nosed kid
in my 20s I
I I very much had as Jonathan mentioned
kind of United Nations imagination the
Christian Reformed Church had a
significant work in the Dominican
Republic I would just had my brand-new
seminary education my head was brimming
with theological ideas and I was going
to go down there we weren't we weren't
pastoring churches we were working with
mostly Haitian pastors who were living
in the Dominican Republic and I thought
I would go down there and be able to be
of all kinds of assistance and I look at
I look at the seven years I was there
sometimes and think I I been if I had to
have benefited way more in those seven
years than any of the people I worked
with I I look back on myself and think
you know they were they were terribly
gracious and kind to put up with me now
part of the reason they put up with me
was because they were working this idea
that via me they could have
relationships that would put them in
touch with resources and networks and
opportunities and and we always resisted
that as a mission because we understood
the corrosive effects of that but
probably the thing that most deeply
impacted me was that by the end of the
time I I had to deeply appreciate how
inadequate I was to actually help that
community and over the time I saw that
many of the efforts similar to what
Jonathan described were some of the best
ways to actually affect long-term change
rather than many of the top-down
approaches that had been tried and in an
island like Hispaniola with the
Dominican Republic in Haiti this has
just been ground zero for how much first
world guilt and imagined you know
triumphalism that that we expressed
religiously and economically towards
these people and the the kind of
long-term dependence that that has
created and I think hobbled in all of
the cultures on that island so it was it
was for me a tremendous education but
also deeply humbling and
it's something that I I very much took
with me into any any ministry I work
here in North America I think I think
one of the medes yes one of the
assumption that I was surprised to see
change I would say or that really helped
to transform my my assumption was really
my vision of art because I I was coming
from a high art world and I had studied
fine art in college and I think I had
become already very disillusioned with
with the contemporary art but I I hadn't
totally understood another way of seeing
art and I've seen the path of making
things with your hands and living with
with artisans in Congo was really
something that was transformed for me to
see people working on objects that the
ground is something very grounded like
the groundedness of their work was
really was really eye-opening to me and
and also the kind of the life of it of
actually making something for someone
there's something there's something in
art this weird idea in art that we find
you know almost as if that if you sell
something you're selling out you know
like if you make something for someone
and you you kind of give in to their
their their need for what you're making
you're selling out but I see it I see it
of a total opposite now I really see it
as entering into communion with some of
your client you partner with your client
and you you you it's a form of
relationship where you talk about you
know creating some object and then you
you create it for them and then you know
that it's actually going to be part of
their lives it's not just gonna be a
status symbol or be something that put
up on their wall to decorate their house
but it's actually going to to to to be
part of their lives and so that that was
a that was something that going into
Africa that I I hadn't I didn't expect
like it was a it was it was a very deep
deep way of seeing art that I that I
held before going that I would say that
the biggest thing that that changed in
terms of my perception of the world it's
interesting cuz we all went overseas up
like different times and and Paul I
think you you going overseas was at a
time when you were a little bit more
idealistic about what was possible but
when I went overseas I there's so many
like horror stories there's so many
when helping her as poverty Inc all
these things that when I went over it
was like well obviously I'm not gonna do
anything productive but it'll be kind of
like a fun thing and so I went in with
really low expectations and then I was
pleasantly surprised that there are
there is the possibility that things can
happen but there is a lot of ineffectual
work as well the thing though I think
they depend I was really lucky because
we ended up leaving with with Mennonites
we were left with Mennonite Central
Committee and MCC there I think they're
one of the best organizations in terms
of the way that they work and they
really prepared us in advance if they
took a lot of time to to kind of prepare
us they would say things like you
shouldn't work for about six months when

language you should create your network
you should connect with people yeah then
once you've done that then only then can
you start to even put your foot out and
and start to see if there's something
you can do to help the community but
that is but that's been really helpful
and the way they work that's how they
really work very locally with local
partners and kind of empowering local
local people that have that already
doing something you know that's not
better that already in a project instead
of coming in with your idea of something
to do and so we were pretty lucky
because before even taking the plane we
we had we had our kind of high hopes of
coming in and saving the world kind of
smash you know slapped out of Central
Committee which I thought was a really
good thing I was gonna say it's it's
important another difference here is
that I worked in church development and
that we partnered with Christian
Reformed what was then World Relief

ethos that that both of you are
describing they they didn't start

partnered with a local you know what
some type of tried to develop a local

in North America we've tended it was
starting in the 90s and it's really
blown up now in terms of the idea that
the churches that the role of the
churches to help people have their best
life now it's kind of an incipient
prosper
gospel and and I think part of what
working with these Haitians taught me
was that I that was just completely
wrung out of me because it was it was
very clear very early on that you know
maybe one or two individuals might
develop a relationship with me and via
that relationship find their way to a
North American seminary and live as one
of this elite class and this whole

majority of the people that I worked
with were going to live brutal difficult
lives their entire life long and so I
had to reorient my mind about what does
it mean to be a Christian in a world of
suffering and and I remember even after
I did one year as an internship and then
I came back to North America to be
formally ordained and then returned and
I remember having kind of sparring with
one of my examiner's on this idea of
realized eschatology he thought I was
basing too much hope in the age to come
and I said look the people I'm working
with that their community is not going
to be rescued this is going to be
difficult and hard for them and they are
going to die poor what does the gospel
mean in that context and so in terms of
theological II that that deeply formed
me and continues to for me today
Jonathan was that your experience as
well like learning about the magnitude
of suffering that exists in the world
when you went overseas you know what was
really what really struck me I think in
in Congo especially in Congo was just
hah I mean first of all like you said
just how difficult people's life were I
mean I often said that if I had to live

and they would try to find some way of

way more joy in Congo that I here you
know I people people are just you know
have a
a lightness of being you know a kind of

they won't they probably won't

I had nothing in front of me I just had

but uh but I had to go through that

well so when I was going overseas I

I play
